ygData.subject: Re: [neat] New HybrID Paper (combining indirect and direct encodings)
ygData.msgSnippet: Thanks to Lucas and Jeff. It s a useful piece of research and a very thorough paper! There s a mention towards the end of the possibility of co-evolving

Subject: Re: [neat] New HybrID Paper (combining indirect and direct encodings)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=K9_jSwNmh4Hff6l-T8-R4yknFiM4i7w8GZKF_GXWcf0PXbGlmieY
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod
From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>


--001a114504bad8a4e0054ba47c2a
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8

Thanks to Lucas and Jeff. It's a useful piece of research and a very
thorough paper!

There's a mention towards the end of the possibility of co-evolving
indirect and direct encodings - I was having the same thought while
reading, as that would essentially be a ensemble (a mini ensemble of two).
Technically we could do this with any encoding, e.g. maybe evolving *pairs*
of NEAT genomes would be superior to single genomes (technically a single
'compound' genome). But of course with the two very different encodings
there's the possibility that we might tap into the strengths of both such.

The poor performance of offset NEAT does seem to suggest that learning
direct encodings early can basically prevent the indirect encoding from
finding the regularities that are there, i.e. the direct encoding
immediately starts to obfuscate them (make the fitness landscape more
complex to search), so it makes sense from that point of view that the
approach has problems, and thus we can probably expect co-evolved genomes
to exhibit the same problem.

Perhaps though the indirect encodings could be scored separately, so two
scores - one based on the indirect encoding genome only, and another for
the compound genome score. We then arrange genomes in a 2D cartesian grid
with one fitness along the X-axis, and compound fitness on the Y-Axis. We
can then define a 'final' fitness score as the distance from the origin
i.e. distance = sqrt(x^2 + y^2).

This has the effect of selecting some genomes that have good indirect
encodings when operating independently, but not when their direct encoding
is applied. This allows the indirect encoding to evolve independently of
the direct encoding, but at some point if the combination works well then
that starts to get selected for, but it still competes for selection with
the indirect only encodings, such that 'branching off' into evolving the
combined pairs is no longer a distinct event, it's just part of the search
space being explored.

Further, a weighting or scaling might be applied to the X-axis or the
Y-axis scores to assign some degree of precedence of preference to the
indirect-only encoding fitness.

Make sense?

Thanks again.

Colin

--001a114504bad8a4e0054ba47c2a
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
